description:
It does not seem to output anything as described, the only interaction that responded to ANY input was command "~$ sudo snap connect liquidctl:hardware-observe" (it asked for my system password).

I then typed "liquidctl list" and it returned to the command line ... (flashing curser only). I did not output any other infomation.

I'm uninstalling ... so sorry ...
Doesn't work at all.. just takes data
Done the permissions, done the commands, only find the MB led controls, not the wonderful list as above. The processor pump goes full rpm and strained humming from processor pump continues.
summary: Don't hate, but doesn't work - sorry

description:
At first I got a few errors, but then everything seemed to stabilize and the tool is able to correctly control and report status from my NZXT H1 V2. This includes both the AIO and the rear case fan.

The liquidctl project seems well maintained. I went to their Github page and there is tons of useful information there about setting it up with systemd and even configuring a script to automatically set your fans based on your CPU temp. The documentation on the Github site is excellent, although I did make some minor changes to the scripts to get them to work on my system (e.g. using Tctl for the CPU temp instead of Tdie).
summary: Works for my NZXT H1 V2
